ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NEIGHBOURHOOD POLICE POST IN CHANGI CONSTITUENCY


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether another Neighbourhood Police Post will be set up in Changi constituency.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) system was introduced more than 10 years ago in 1983. Since then, there have been significant

Column: 668

shifts in the population due to the setting up of new towns. As a result, some of the existing NPPs are no longer strategically located.

    Police is currently reviewing the NPP system, taking into account these shifts in population. The request by Mr Teo will be considered in the review.

PRIVATE AND GOVERNMENT GENERAL CLINICS
(Attendances)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Health if he will (i) give the percentage of attendances at private and Government general clinics for the years 1992 to 1994 and (ii) consider extending the visiting hours in Government general clinics or providing more clinics in order to increase attendances.

     The Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the attendances at private general practitioner (GP) clinics are estimated once every five years based on surveys conducted by the Ministry. The surveys done were in 1988 and 1993. In 1988, GPs attended to 80% and Government clinics 20% of the total number of patients. The 1993 survey showed a slight increase in the proportion of patients seen by the GPs at 82%.

    The pattern of illnesses seen at GP clinics differs somewhat from those seen at Government clinics. GP clinics attend to more of acute conditions with a lower proportion of chronic conditions. Government clinics, however, see a higher proportion of chronic conditions, such as high blood pressure and diabetes. These are conditions requiring long-term care and management.

    Attendances at Government clinics have fallen for two main reasons. First, there are now more GP clinics which are conveniently located near patients' homes. Second, with higher incomes, most Singaporeans can afford to consult GPs. As most GP clinics are open at night, there is no need for Government clinics to extend their operating hours. We also have a 24-hour clinic at Singapore General

Column: 669

Hospital for non-emergency cases. We will continue to build Government clinics in HDB new towns where there is a need for such services.

OVER-CHARGING BY DOCTORS
(Public education)


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Health whether his Ministry has any plans to educate the general public to ensure that they will not be over-charged by doctors for over-prescription and investigation.

     Dr Aline Wong (for the Minister for Health): Sir, the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act, implemented in 1994, requires all private and public health care establishments to inform every patient on or before admission of the estimated charges which are likely to be incurred for hospitalisation, investigation and treatment. Every medical practitioner is required to provide information to the patient on the consultation, investigation and treatment charges. Every licensed clinical laboratory must provide a printed list of charges to doctors or patients on the laboratory tests to be performed.

    The Ministry ensures that these requirements are complied with during licensing. Regular inspection of health care establishments has shown that the hospitals are complying with this requirement. The public is also provided with additional information on hospital charges through displays of notices, brochures and pamphlets which are freely available at the A&E, outpatient, wards and other public areas of the hospitals.

    To prevent over-prescription or over-investigation, hospitals are required to conduct regular in-house medical audits of the doctor's prescribing practices.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio GRC): Sir, I know that most of the Government hospitals and clinics would advise the

Column: 670

public about the charges. How about the private clinics? I strongly feel that the private clinics should display their charges, especially the common illnesses, so that the general public would know that they are not being over-charged by the doctors.

     Dr Aline Wong: As I said just now, the private clinics are also required under the licensing Act to display their charges. A survey conducted in 1993 by the Ministry's Medical Audit and Accreditation Unit to assess the status of display of charges at the medical clinics prior to the implementation of the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act at 100 randomly selected private medical clinics showed that at that time only 40% of the clinics displayed information on charges. However, by the end of 1994, information obtained during the licensing of medical and dental clinics showed that 100% of them have complied with this requirement of display of charges in the clinics.

Column: 670

MEDICAL STAFF IN POLYCLINICS
(Increase in number)


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Health if his Ministry will consider increasing the medical staff in polyclinics so as to reduce the present waiting time.

     Dr Aline Wong (for the Minister for Health): Sir, the Ministry would be able to post more doctors to polyclinics by the middle of this year. This would help to reduce waiting time somewhat.

    However, waiting time at the polyclinics depends not only on the number of doctors but also on the arrival time of the patients. The waiting time at peak hours is longer than at non-peak hours. In general, the median waiting time to see the polyclinic doctor after registration, as shown in a January 1994 survey, was 19 minutes. Patients who require repeat visits to the polyclinics are given appointments during off-peak hours. We have been educating polyclinic patients to keep to their appointments.

Column: 671

LOYANG AVENUE/TAMPINES EXPRESSWAY/UPPER CHANGI ROAD NORTH
(Improvement to roads)


    5. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Acting Minister for National Development whether the roads in the vicinity of Loyang Avenue, Tampines Expressway and Upper Changi Road North will be improved to accommodate the increasing vehicular traffic during peak hours.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Matthias Yao Chih) (for the Acting Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Works Department has plans for improvement projects to accommodate the increasing vehicular traffic in the vicinity of Loyang Avenue, Tampines Expressway (TPE) and Upper Changi Road North.

    A section of Loyang Avenue from Pasir Ris Drive 3 to TPE will be widened in 1996. Loyang Avenue's junction with Pasir Ris Drive 1 and Drive 3 will be improved as part of the road widening project. The present interchange of the TPE with the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE) will be upgraded in 1997. In the upgrading, new flyovers will link the PIE with the TPE. The TPE will be linked to the Seletar Expressway (SLE) and Central Expressway (CTE) with the completion of the interchange at Lorong Halus in 1997.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Sir, last

Column: 672

Friday, Dr Kanwaljit Soin criticised media portrayal of women and the exploitation of sexual themes on the pages of women's magazines. Ironically, most of the editors of these women's magazines are themselves women. I agree with Dr Soin on the unnecessary and excessive use of sexual themes on the front covers of women's magazines. In fact, last month, MITA issued a statement warning these publications not to overplay sex and sexual themes. My officers called up the editors of Elle, Cleo, Her World, Go, Beverly, Marie Claire and Female. The editor of Female was specifically warned about the article on phone sex which Dr Soin referred to. They know MITA's position and should not be surprised if, as a result of further such transgressions, action is taken against them in the future, including the suspension of their licences. The danger is if we do nothing, there will be competitive pressure on them to go downhill collectively and it was for this reason that a few years ago we decided not to allow Cosmopolitan in because it would then become a pace-setter.

    On the deeper issue of women's place in our society, there are many views and I do not propose to go into a debate on them. Naturally one expects that some of these differences of opinion should be reflected in the way they are covered in the media. I think what we can all agree on is that the integrity of the family is crucial and to ensure that our children are well brought up and the correct values transmitted, strong mothers are necessary in our culture. Indeed, if we look at the trading communities which have retained their sense of self in different parts of the world, communities like Punjabis and Sindhis, communities like Jews, the Chinese in America, the Lebanese in West Africa, the recurrent factor is strong families built around a strong mother who is a tremendous source of influence on the children.

    In Singapore's case, of particular concern is the need to get our womenfolk to marry, to marry younger, to have children and to have children younger. That is the key to everything else. On other issues, I think we can have a healthy debate.

    Both Mr Kenneth Chen and Mr Peter Sung commented on the Esplanade, the Singapore Arts Centre. I would like to reply to Mr Kenneth Chen's comment on the design of the Esplanade. Many criticisms of the Esplanade exhibition last year resulted from a misunderstanding of what the model represented. When we conducted the exhibition the design process was at a certain stage. The model was intended to show the massing configuration. In other words, we had already decided in our minds what the centre should do. We should have five theatres, two big halls and three small ones. It should be a lively place, well used throughout the day, throughout the week. We also wanted it to be a place which all Singaporeans can identify with.

    On the basis of these considerations, the architects came up with a massing design and we decided not to put the various halls, especially the big halls, under one roof because on the particular site, and it is a wonderful site, on Marina Bay it would have been too big. If we transpose something of the size of Sydney Opera House which is at the end of a promontory at the entrance of Sydney Harbour right into the heart of the city centre in Singapore it would have been humongous and would be totally out of proportion with the civic buildings around and with the buildings in Marina Central. For this reason, the Steering Committee decided that the big halls should be separately located but linked together in a light way so that the centre as a whole would not be too big and too overpowering.

    Having said that, each hall is designed from inside. In other words, first, we decide on what kind of stage we need, how many seats we are going to have, then we optimise on sightlines, we optimise on acoustics. In other words, every hall is mathematically designed and once you decide that a particular hall should stand in a particular place, therefore, it takes a particular shape. But it is not true that piling work would be starting soon. In fact, when the exhibition was held, the detailed design work had not even started and we are right now in the midst of it. So I would

Column: 674

like to assure Mr Chen that the model which was represented does not reflect what the final design will be, and the buildings will be neither white nor will they look like blobs.

    As to consultation with local architects and other members of the Singaporean community, in fact, extensive consultations were carried out. The Singapore Institute of Architects was itself represented on the Steering Committee and a special group called the Design and Aesthetics Advisory Group was set up, consisting of architects and members of the Faculty of Architecture from the National University of Singapore. They, together with other groups representing the arts community, impresarios, those who are interested in arts in Singapore, were extensively consulted and the design process was an interactive and iterative one between them and the architects. In fact, President Ong, himself an architect, who used to chair the Committee, remains as an advisor to the Committee and takes a very keen interest in the actual design of the centre.

    Mr Peter Sung expressed very valid concerns about the use of the Arts Centre and the importance of not allowing it to turn into a white elephant. We have been very conscious of this from the start and to ensure that the Esplanade is designed to cater to both eastern and western art forms with formal and informal spaces, it is not intended to be only for a small group of people from the cultural elite. In fact, there will be many restaurants and there will be food outlets like the Satay Club.

    I am very happy that in the latest design of the LRT for that part of the city, there will be a station right at the Arts Centre itself.

    We hope and we have designed the Esplanade for major civic events like the Lunar New Year River Hongbao Show, for public events like New Year's Eve Countdowns, Singapore Swing, and so on. And we are confident that the Esplanade will be a centre which all Singaporeans will be proud of and can identify with.

Column: 675



    Our intention is not to build an entertainment complex or an amusement park. Our intention at the end of the day is to build a cultural centre, indeed a cultural temple, which all Singaporeans can take emotional and spiritual references to. That is the objective and that is the reason why such a wonderful site has been set aside for it and so much effort is going into its construction.

     The Chairman: You have a few minutes more.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, with your indulgence, I would like to cover very quickly Mr Peh Chin Hua's concerns about how we honour patrons and donors at the National Museum.

    He raised the loss of the Low Chuck Tiew's collections in 1991 to Hong Kong. In fact, it could not have been avoided because at that time our museum was not prepared for it. I had the good fortune to meet Mr Low Chuck Tiew a few years before he passed away, to speak to him, to learn from him - a very erudite scholar. He had lived in Hong Kong for 40 years, felt very strong pulls to Hong Kong and felt a responsibility to leave his collection there.

    Since 1991, the National Museum itself has gone through a profound transformation and it is no longer a museum principally for South-east Asia, but a museum which also caters to all the other cultural and heritage links that we have with China, with India and other parts of Asia. Because of this, a number of important donations have been made, some of which were mentioned by Mr Peh Chin Hua. In addition, a few major Hong Kong collectors have also agreed to loan their exhibitions to Singapore. Some had already been exhibited here.

    We still do not have enough space. The SJI Museum will be ready this year, Tao Nan's next year, and the refurbished Empress Place Building will only be ready two or three years from now. So for the time being, because we are hard up for spaces, some of our better items may have to be in storage temporarily. But I take Mr Peh Chin Hua's point that we

Column: 676

should always honour patrons, benefactors and donors in an appropriate way. It may not always be possible to dedicate halls and buildings to them, because once we do so we cannot change these names, but it is a point I will consider and shall urge the National Heritage Board to consider.

     Mr Peter Sung (Buona Vista): Sir, I have read with interest the reports of the Advisory Committee on TCS' Chinese drama and variety shows and also the assessment of the Censorship Feedback Panel 1994. Both these Committees are appointed by MITA. They have surveyed and got opinions of other people. They have also put in their own views. The reports are now with MITA and now MITA must decide, as it should be.

    In matters of government, the Government takes the lead. This has always been the case, Sir. For example, in the case of shared values, yes, there was dialogue, there was consultation. But the process was certainly government-led. In the case also of Confucian values for Chinese Singaporeans, the Government took the lead to distil from the past, from all the studies, the values that are relevant for modern Singapore. My point is that the Government sets the tone and must continue to lead.

    Sir, this year's debate has been lively. I would thank all Members who spoke, for their contributions, and also thank the Minister for his replies.

    I like this year's debate better than last year's. Since we last spoke, many improvements have been made. Backbenchers now realise that their pleas have not fallen on deaf ears. And before he came to this House, the Minister in fact made many arrangements to improve programmes, controls and censorship to the point that the remarks made by Members this year were much better.

     Mr Peter Sung: Sir, the Minister in his reply has acknowledged MPs' contributions and also said that he would look into

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon South)( In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code RB 1500.

    Sir, for many years, we have been holding Courtesy Campaigns every year. After many years of effort, we have achieved some results. For example, better quality of service can be observed at public service counters, hotels, taxi-drivers, etc. However, there is still room for improvement.

    However, there are two areas where no improvement has been made. One is the sales persons at departmental stores and the other is the notorious motorists in Singapore.

    Singapore has always prided itself as a shoppers' paradise. Is that a fact? Just a few days ago, a Member of this House said that retailers were suffering a decline in their business. Tourists do not buy as much as before and local people are going overseas to do their shopping. The bad attitude of sales persons in our retail outlets will certainly affect the status of Singapore as a shoppers' paradise. People who have travelled overseas will know that in many countries the service personnel in the shops and departmental stores are very good. They are very helpful and very courteous. They give the impression that they like the job and are proud to be able to service their customers. On the other hand, take a look at the sales persons in the shops in Singapore. Their attitude is deplorable. Their attitude is like that of the sales persons in the state-owned departmental stores in the communist countries.

    Why should our service personnel in the shops adopt such a bad attitude? I think the main reason is that, firstly, they

Column: 678

lack professional training; secondly, their pay is too low; and thirdly, they have no incentive to serve well. I know that this does not come within the portfolio of MITA, but I think in the overall Courtesy Campaign, more attention can be given to this aspect, and I think we can achieve some result.

    Now let me talk about the Singapore motorists. Their attitude is truly very bad. Compared to most cities in other countries, I think our traffic condition is quite good. We have a good road network, good traffic management, and we do not have frequent traffic jams. But our motorists are notorious. They are the worst lot, as compared to their counterparts in other parts of the world. There are, of course, some good and courteous motorists in Singapore, but I regret to say that there are also many bad and discourteous motorists. They are impatient, inconsiderate, and do not care about the interest, convenience and safety of other road users. They never give way to others. They hog the road. They drive at excessive speeds. They change lanes as and when they want without due care and concern for others. They fight for vacant lots in the car park. These are happening every day on our roads.

    Sir, are Singaporeans so bad, so discourteous? I do not think so. But I have noticed that people who are ordinarily courteous and well-mannered simply turn into monsters the moment they take the driver's seat. Why is it so? Is this the national characteristic of Singaporean's kiasu attitude?

     The Chairman: Dr Koh, we do not have much time left.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin( In Mandarin): I hope that in the next Courtesy Campaign, some attention will be given to this problem.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Information and the Arts (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M): Sir, Dr Koh Lip Lin raised several points regarding the Courtesy Campaign in Singapore. When the Campaign was launched in 1979, it was clear to the Government and the Ministry concerned that we are into a programme that will

Column: 679

take a long time to be successful. In fact, it takes a long time to change social habits. And the ultimate objective is to try to make Singapore a more gracious nation where people are more courteous to each other and there is a more pleasant environment, not just between the public and the Government departments but also in the private sector.

    So far, since the Campaign was launched in 1979, there has been progress made, as the Member noted in his speech. Every year, the Ministry, now through the National Courtesy Council, always targets the general population through the July Campaign, and we also target certain sectors, depending on the needs. We have also run regular surveys on alternate years and every survey has indicated that we have made progress. Of course, it does not mean that we have achieved our objective.

    We still have some way to go and in this respect, Sir. the National Courtesy Council works closely with the Singapore Retail Merchants' Association to address some of the concerns raised by the Member about sales staff at department stores and others. We also work with the Singapore Manufacturers' Association, even the Singapore Hotels' Association, to raise the level of courtesy in all these industries. As an example, there is the "Service Gold" award where the National Courtesy Council gives out jointly with the Singapore Hotels' Association. Last year, there were a total of 35 winners under this award. There was a survey done in 1993 and 1994. On the whole, Sir, the result of the survey showed that about 7% were found to be less courteous than before and in 1993, 94% of workers in department stores were found to be as courteous as before or even more courteous than before. So these indications show that, on the whole, we have made progress among the sales staff. It cannot be denied that there are some who will remain somewhat discourteous for one reason or another.

    Sir, courtesy begets courtesy. I think when the general public in Singapore goes shopping, it is expected that we should also be courteous to the sales staff

Column: 680

and others. And it is normally found that those who are courteous to these people will be treated with courtesy too.

     The Chairman: Order. Mr Maidin, we have run out of time on this amendment.

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Just one more point raised by the Member about courtesy on the road. Sir, he could be right that there is some element of kiasuism at work on our roads. On the whole, although there has been improvement, the National Courtesy Council would continue to work closely with the Traffic Police to improve its public education programmes and campaign annually. In addition to the various activities, road courtesy is also being taught as part of the training syllabus at the driving centres and the objective is to inculcate the correct attitudes and habits right at the outset. I understand that the Traffic Police will again organise a courtesy campaign in July this year and the National Courtesy Council will work with them closely to raise the level of courtesy on the roads.

     The Chairman: Amendment No. (3), Mr Goh. Can I remind the Member that "guillotine" time is 1.15 pm?

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code RC 1500.

    Sir, according to the Library 2000 Review Committee, there are plans for community libraries in various parts of the island, including Serangoon New Town in the town centre. I would like to know what is the time-frame for the construction of this library.

    Sir, there are currently 19,157 units of HDB flats in Serangoon Town and 1,665 more are under construction. The total population of the town should be in the region of 80,000 to 100,000 and taking into consideration the nearby estates as well as private housing estates, the number should be much bigger. The

Column: 681

nearest libraries for these residents, at the moment, are Ang Mo Kio and Toa Payoh Branch Libraries. They are not easily accessible. So I would like to urge the Minister to give priority consideration for the construction of community libraries for Serangoon New Town and other towns which are without branch or regional libraries.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin: Sir, I just want to ask two simple questions. First, I have noted from the Annual Report of the National Library that, despite the increasing membership of the National Library over the years, the number of books borrowed per member per year has been declining steadily over the past few years. The Report cited "library under renovation" as the reason, but my concern is that the real reason may be that Singaporeans are reading less. May I ask what steps will be taken to promote the reading habits of Singaporeans?

     The Minister for Health (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Sir, first, let me thank Members for making some very thoughtful comments about the direction of our national health policies. Everything we do, whether it involves medical excellence, the practice of traditional Chinese medicine, medical ethics, insurance, subsidies must have, as its starting and its end points, our demographic structure.

    At the debate on the Finance Minister's Budget speech, Mr Ling How Doong said that we were spending too little money on health, we were being stingy. He said that we were spending only 1.2%. He misunderstood the numbers. Dr Richard Hu said we are, in fact, spending 3% of our GDP. I have asked my officials to do modelling exercises of what the burden on our total society would be in the future if we maintain the same level of health care for each generation. Because the key thing to remember here is that we are still a very young population and when we are young, we do not spend very much on health care. But when we are old, health care costs rise exponentially. And in fact the different models show that, based upon the existing level of health care, we will reach 6% to 8% in the early part of the next century.

    The demographics are like so. After the Second World War, we had a post-war baby boom and many of us here are in fact members of that generation. From 1945 to 1966, when KK Hospital entered the Guinness Book of Records for being the world's busiest baby factory and, after that, if you look at the demographic charts, our population birth rate plummeted. Now this bulge in our demographic profile will affect everything that we do in Singapore - housing, politics, health care, education. Mindef

Column: 704

faced it in the late 80s when suddenly it found that fewer and fewer young men were entering national service and they had to resize their ORBAT accordingly.

    We will age gradually between now and 2010. But after 2010, when the post-war baby boomers march into their winter years, when they are 65 and above, we will age rapidly until about 2030, when those who were born and gave KK Hospital the Guinness Book award reach their post-65 era. After 2030, it will begin to improve. But for 20 years, we will be in a very vulnerable period when something like one in four of us will be over 65 years of age and that will be a very different kind of Singapore, it will be a different kind of Parliamentary Chamber.

    Everything that we do now carries implications deep into the future and we must ensure that what we do now anticipates the problem of the next century. If we do not, come that particular time, the burden on young people will be so heavy, they will emigrate and Singapore can collapse. I think in all discussions, let us bear in mind that every good deed that we do now has got downstream implications way into the future and really we have a tremendous responsibility to so structure our health system that come 2010, it is something which a younger generation of Singaporeans at that time can bear comfortably.

It is therefore very important for us not to be associated with it. What we are trying to do is to ease the process of the inevitable, not to hasten it.

    Many points have been made. Extensive consultations have been made by the National Medical Ethics Committee with various religious and professional groups in Singapore. Why religious groups? Because this is a question of life and death and, therefore, a question which touches on the spiritual nature of life itself and is something which all religious people will naturally have views upon, and views of religious leaders having tremendous influence on their flocks.

    We have not been rushing it. Over the last one year, extensive consultations have been made with 24 religious groups and professional bodies. Most of them are in agreement with the principles, except for one or two. A few asked whether it is necessary now and said perhaps we can wait. On the whole, the support is very great. And the Mufti himself, I remember, issued a fatwa saying that it is something acceptable to Islam.

    Let me be very specific here, to answer the reservations of Mr Loh Meng See

Column: 707

and Dr Tan Cheng Bock, that it will be strictly voluntary. No one is forced to do an advance directive. No one will be pressured to do it. In fact, we must have laws which will go after those who pressure people to write advance directives. It is something completely of their free will. If you do not understand it, if you do not want to preoccupy yourself with it, then leave it.

    But whether or not there are advance directives, the dilemma of how to treat people who are dying will remain for as long as there is human civilization, and it will remain for as long as we are mortal. Because come the final moment, someone must decide: do I resuscitate one more time? Do I go for yet more expensive antibiotics to fight the final pneumonia which will knock the patient off? At the end of the day, it is a deeply spiritual and a deeply personal matter as to how I register my preferences. If I do it well, consult my wife and family members, I will ease their pains later. If I avoid the issue and leave it to them, when I am no longer compos mentis, and there are quarrels within the family, decisions are taken, you can have recriminations for years after that, when other tensions arise in the family and people say, "There you are, you killed my mother," or "You didn't give enough care to her."

    So where individuals, having looked at the experiences of others, decide, "Look, I better make preparations, do my will and give clear instructions. Do I want to be buried? Do I want to be cremated? How do I want the final days to be ordered?" By the person settling these issues before he passes away, he takes away a lot of that burden from his wife and his family members, and this is really what advance directives are intended to do, not to force anyone. But if they decide to have an input, then they can. The law will allow for it.

    It has got nothing to do with medical cost. Because, as I said, even if you have no advance directives, the issue of when to pull the plug will still be there.

    Why has the problem now arisen when it did not in the past? In the old days when

life was simpler, doctors were taught that when patients were dying, they did what was called "masterly inactivity". This was told to me by members of his family whom I know quite well. And I thought that he died a wonderful death. to regulate and upgrade the practice of traditional Chinese medicine. Having raised the issue last year, I must now register a caveat, that while we should do something to improve training and regulation, it is not easy. If it were so easy, it would have been done in Japan, in Korea, in Taiwan, in China, in Hong Kong. It is done in none of these countries. Even in China, where there are a number of top TCM universities, the syllabuses, and the codification vary from university to university. And the health ministry there regulates with a very light hand. During Mao Ze Dong's days, when they had barefoot doctors, he insisted that there be integration of western and eastern medicine. The same spirit caused Mr Peh Chin Hua to recommend that we set up a centre for eastern and western medical studies.

    But, in reality, in China, even though they require the two disciplines to be put together, there is no real integration. If you are a student in a western medical school, they call it xi yi wei zhu [ ]. You must still do some zhong yi [ ]. You must still do some eastern medicine. If you go to a TCM institute, zhong yi wei zhu [ ] , you must still do some western medicine. So you do 70%-80% of one and 20%-30% of the other, which is why today when you meet a sinseh from China, he understands ultrasound, he understands X-rays and he can talk to you about viruses and bacteria and immune systems. In the same way, when we meet a western doctor from China, they are quite knowledgeable in qi, acupuncture and herbs. But there is no integration in the sense of scientific integration.

    This is an area which has bedeviled scientists for many decades. I remember reading once an essay by the great Cambridge historian, Joseph Needhan, who wrote this encyclopedic study on Science and Civilization in China. And he said, in every field there is integration - in astronomy, geography, science, navigation, the whole range, except in medicine. He said, on this last field, integration remains very difficult. And the reason, I believe, is because western medicine takes an analytical approach

and, in fact, remarkable progress is being done at the molecular and the genetic level. But eastern medicine tends to take as its starting point holistic medicine. Progress is advancing, curiously, in both directions.

Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Finance, in regard to the $3 million given to the Citizens' Consultative Committees to help low-income families to apply for grants to offset GST, (a) what is the number of families who have made use of this scheme; (b) has the scheme been adequately publicized; and (c) has the scheme been adequately used and, if not, what are the reasons.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau:

    (a) As of 13th March 1995, a total of 24 families have been given assistance under the Citizens' Consultative Committee (CCC) Assistance Scheme.

    (b) The Scheme was publicised in a press statement issued on 30th March 1994. Details of the Scheme were also circulated to all CCCs at the same time prior to the launch of the Scheme on 1st April 1994.

    (c) The purpose of the CCC Assistance Scheme is to ensure that the GST does not make low income families worse off. The utilisation of the Scheme was never expected to be high because of the generous GST offset measures introduced, which have been more than sufficient to offset the GST expenditure in most instances, in particular, those living in HDB flats. As a result, very few low income families have become worse off on account of GST to warrant assistance under the Scheme.

WAIVER OF STANDARD MISCELLANEOUS FEES


    2. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Education if he will (i) give the number of school children who have applied for waiver of standard miscellaneous fees for the last 3 years in secondary schools; (ii) consider giving students from needy families, 100% instead of the present 50% waiver of standard miscellaneous fees; and (iii) disseminate information of this financial assistance scheme to each child in all languages when the child first enters secondary school.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan:

    (i) For the school year 1995, 1276 children in secondary schools were granted waiver of standard miscellaneous fees. The numbers were 1369 in 1994, and 1067 in 1993.

    (ii) Granting waiver of 50% of standard miscellaneous fees is in line with the Government's philosophy that parents must be responsible for the education of their children. Hence, parents are required to pay a token amount of the fee to instil this sense of responsibility.

    (iii) Information of this financial assistance scheme is made known to parents who have difficulty in paying the token fees. On top of that, principals will refer needy children to community and charitable organisations for further financial assistance.

TERTIARY INSTITUTIONS


    3. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Education, in view of the large number of our students going abroad to study in tertiary institutions, if he will consider allowing some reputable tertiary institutions to start twinning programmes in Singapore to reduce the inconvenience and expense to our local students.

Column: 775



     Mr Lee Yock Suan:

    Some private organisations in Singapore are already offering various modes of degree programmes in collaboration with foreign universities. They include correspondence courses, distance-learning courses, external degree programmes and open university degree programmes, and can be undertaken on a full-time or part-time basis.

    A twinning programme involves a formal agreement between a local institution and a particular overseas university to run a split-site programme in which students undertake the first part of the programme in the local institution and then proceed to the overseas university for the final part of the programme. Although there is no formal twinning arrangement, various universities overseas allow our polytechnic graduates advanced placement in their degree programmes.

    The Ministry is studying carefully whether it is necessary and desirable to further facilitate the offer of foreign degree programmes to Singapore students, bearing in mind that the two local universities and four polytechnics will already cater for 60% of each age cohort of students. In addition, many students prefer to study overseas for personal and other reasons. The graduate output must be guided by our manpower demands and befit the structure of our economy, including our regionalisation efforts, to minimise graduate unemployment or under-employment in the future. The quality and standard of education in Singapore must be maintained.

SUBDIVISION OF INDIANS


    4. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Home Affairs the reasons for subdividing Indians into different categories such as Sri Lankans, Ceylonese, Punjabis and Tamils in the new Identity card, when (i) there are no such subdivisions for the Malays and Chinese and (ii) there is no such thing as a Sri Lankan race, only a Sri Lankan national.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

    Subdividing Indians and others into different categories is a practice since the first identity cards were issued by the colonial government. Registration officers recorded a person's race based on what the applicant declared. There is no policy to distinguish "Sri Lankans" from "Ceylonese" or "Punjabi" or other categories of Indians in the new NRIC programme.

    Sub-divisions are not unique to Indians. In fact, there are many sub-groups under the "Malay" category e.g. Javanese, Boyanese, Minangkabau, Dayaks, and Ibans.

    It is true that the term "Sri Lankan" is also a nationality. The fact remains that persons coming from Sri Lanka are now known as Sri Lankans and not Ceylonese. The National Registration Department has been approving requests to change one's race from "Sri Lankan" back to "Ceylonese".

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo:
